Column Comment.0: SEISMIC SET SUBTYPE: The seismic set type column is used to enforce arelationship between the SEIS SET supertype and its valid sub types. Values for thiscolumn must be the name of the table that is the valid sub type for this row of data.Valid entries include SEIS_LINE, SEIS_SEGMENT, SEIS_SURVEY, SEIS_PLAN,SEIS_WELL, SEIS_PROC_SET, SEIS_INTERP_SET or SEIS_3D.
Column Comment.1: SEISMIC PROCESSING SET: unique identifier for a set of data that will beprocessed as a unit. The processing set may be a single line, a portion of a line, agroup of lines, a 3D survey, a portion of a 3D survey or a compilation of several.Details about what seismic sets are being processed is captured in the table SEISPROC COMPONENT.
Column Comment.2: PROCESSING COMPONENT: Unique identifier for the input or output to theprocessing set.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: BIN_GRID_ID: Unique identifier for the bin grid
Column Comment.5: BIN_GRID_SOURCE: The source of the bin grid data
Column Comment.6: SEISMIC SET: A seismic set is a super type of various types of seismic collections.
Column Comment.7: SEISMIC SET SUBTYPE: The seismic set type column is used to enforce arelationship between the SEIS SET supertype and its valid sub types. Values for thiscolumn must be the name of the table that is the valid sub type for this row of data.Valid entries include SEIS_LINE, SEIS_SEGMENT, SEIS_SURVEY, SEIS_PLAN,SEIS_WELL, SEIS_PROC_SET, SEIS_INTERP_SET or SEIS_3D.
Column Comment.8: EFFECTIVE DATE: the date on which this row of data first came into effect from abusiness perspective.
Column Comment.9: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.10: INFORMATION ITEM ID: Unique identifier for the information item.
Column Comment.11: INFORMATION ITEM SUBTYPE: the type of information item. May be one of Thevalid types of Information item as defined by check constraints.
Column Comment.12: INPUT INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether the component is an input to theprocessing.
Column Comment.13: OUTPUT INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether the component is an outputfrom the processing.
Column Comment.14: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.15: PROCESSING COMPONENT TYPE: The type of processing component, such asseismic data, velocity survey etc.
Column Comment.16: REMARK: Narrative remarks relating to this row of data.
Column Comment.17: SEISMIC PROCESSING PLAN IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for the seismicprocessing plan that was prepared. This plan may be referenced in a contract with aprocessing house and should form the starting point of most processing sequences.
Column Comment.18: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.19: UNIQUE WELL IDENTIFIER: A unique name, code or number designated as theprimary key for this row.
Column Comment.20: VELOCITY VOLUME IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for this velocity volume.
Column Comment.21: CURVE IDENTIFIER: Unique identification number assigned to the curve or trace.
Column Comment.22: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.23: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.24: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.25: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.26: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.27: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.28: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
